title: 107_hr2545
content: The Flood Loss Mitigation Act of 2001, also known as the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968, includes provisions for mitigation and purchase of certain repetitive loss structures. The Flood Loss Mitigation Act of 2001 authorizes the Director to carry out mitigation activities and purchase qualified repetitive loss structures for public or open space use. Limitations are established to encourage participation in the national flood insurance program. The Flood Loss Mitigation Act of 2001 authorizes the Director to carry out mitigation activities and purchase qualified repetitive loss structures for public or open space use, with limitations to encourage participation in the national flood insurance program. These limitations include prohibitions on using funds for mitigation or purchase if it interferes with purchasing a replacement residence, if flooding was caused by third party development, if it disrupts preservation of historically significant properties, or if the owner relied on purchasing the structure. The Director can prioritize mitigation for qualified repetitive loss structures based on their impact on the National Flood Insurance Fund. The Act prohibits using funds for mitigation if it hinders purchasing a replacement residence, was caused by third party development, disrupts preservation of historically significant properties, or if the owner relied on purchasing the structure. The Director may issue obligations to the Treasury to fund this section, with terms set by the Treasury. Congress must be notified 25 days before issuance. The Secretary of the Treasury may purchase obligations issued under this subsection using proceeds from the sale of securities. The total amount of outstanding obligations held by the Secretary cannot exceed $300,000,000. The Secretary of the Treasury has the authority to sell obligations issued under this subsection. All transactions involving these obligations are considered public debt transactions of the United States. A "qualified repetitive loss structure" is defined as a structure that has incurred flood-related damage. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations totaling $250,000,000 for fiscal years 2002 to 2005 is provided for activities under this section. SEC. 3. TREATMENT OF SAVINGS. Section 1310 of the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to allow for the use of mitigation savings under subsection (g) of the section. The Director is required to determine the portion of the fund's amounts attributable to savings from mitigation activities and purchases for qualified repetitive loss structures. In each fiscal year, an amount in the fund equal to the amount determined under subsection (g) shall be available only for mitigation activities and purchase of qualified repetitive loss structures. The Director may use funds for mapping after a certain percentage of structures have been mitigated or purchased for public use. The Director can use up to 75 percent of the reserved amount each fiscal year for mapping activities under section 1360, with sound land management policies in place. SEC. 4. INELIGIBILITY FOR NATIONAL FLOOD INSURANCE PROGRAM. Amends Section 1316 of the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 to prohibit coverage for certain properties. The amendment adds new subsections regarding qualified repetitive loss structures, allowing the Director to deny or cancel flood insurance coverage for properties that refuse mitigation activities. The Director can also increase the risk premium rate for new coverage on such properties. The Director can deny or cancel flood insurance coverage for properties with fraudulent claims, and owners can appeal within 90 days. The Director can deny or cancel flood insurance coverage for properties with fraudulent claims, and owners can appeal within 90 days to an independent third party for a final determination.
